stream_context.summary: Kaze mainly brainstorms and locks in the five remaining course themes for Over-world 3, reviews the nearly-finished Bowser fight, and briefly stress-tests the hack on real N64 hardware while fielding chat ideas.

development_findings.summary: Bowser fight logic is complete; only animations, SFX, VFX, and an intro cut-scene remain before it is final.
development_findings.quote: The Bowser fight is basically finished. It just needs animations, sound effects and visual effects.

development_findings.summary: Animations are blocked on Zeina; Kaze will implement effects after receiving them.
development_findings.quote: We are waiting for Zeina's animation first before I implement all that.

development_findings.summary: Course count for the hack is fixed at 15. Over-world 3 still required five full courses and two side levels; today’s stream selected the final five.
development_findings.quote: We have five more level slots left… Right now we have seven level ideas, but… you need to come up with more ideas so you can discard the bad ones.

development_findings.summary: Final list of Over-world 3 courses: Course 11 Frantic Fleet Factory (Bowser’s airship yard), Course 12 Wild West Valley (detective/outlaw), Course 13 Music/Mario Paint world, Course 14 Casino with Dr Mario retro pipe, Course 15 Super-hero comic city with mirror ‘dark world’.

Each new course gets a ‘retro pipe’ cameo; assignments made: Frantic Fleet Factory → Smash 64 ‘board the platforms’, Wild West Valley → Paper Mario 64, Music world → Mario Paint styled, Casino → Dr Mario, Comic city → Mario Land.
Dropped/downsized ideas: computer level and ice-cream train moved to side levels; water levels rejected; medieval castle and hot-cold gimmicks deemed too limiting.
development_findings.quote: A computer level… kinda sucks because it was already Lost Impact… Ice-cream got delegated to just a side course.

development_findings.summary: Design philosophy emphasised: generate many ideas, then pick the best; mechanics must be easy to understand; avoid over-complex or purely aesthetic gimmicks.
development_findings.quote: You should come up with 15 ideas and use 5 of them… It’s good to have a complex game as long as it’s easy to understand.

development_findings.summary: Performance milestone: game now sustains 30 FPS widescreen on real N64; earlier complex cave level cannot dip below 30 even when forced.
development_findings.quote: I can’t even get below 30 FPS… people said the N64 couldn’t run this.

development_findings.summary: Kaze tested a new 20 FPS interpolation technique but current performance is too high to showcase it.
development_findings.quote: I wanted to show you guys my new 20 FPS interpolation… but I just can't get the FPS that low.

development_findings.summary: NTSC is the only target region; no separate PAL build planned.

Frantic Fleet Factory star layout drafted: sabotage minions to start strike, topple Bowser statue with crane, fight strike-breaking boss, construction beam red-coins, breakable-block demolition star, etc.

context_findings.summary: Kaze stresses that decision-making sessions are as valuable as coding and directly impact game quality.
context_findings.quote: No matter how hard you work, if you don't make good decisions, your game's gonna be shit.

context_findings.summary: He dislikes water levels and low-FPS ‘stylised’ animation; seeks fun, readable mechanics.
context_findings.quote: I don't like water levels… I don't want characters to animate at low FPS.

context_findings.summary: Kaze moved streaming from Twitch to YouTube due to excessive ads and better long-term prospects.
context_findings.quote: Yeah, I'm streaming on YouTube now… Twitch has so many ads, I can't stand it anymore.

context_findings.summary: Philosophy on learning ROM hacking: remake something until it’s good; choose decomp if willing to invest 100+ hours, otherwise ROM hacks.
context_findings.quote: If the results are bad, just keep working on it until the results are good… If you're determined to spend the next 100 hours, do decomp; if not, ROM-making is fine.

biobak.summary: Kaze contemplates asking Biobak to handle large asset tasks (e.g., Mario Paint notes) but hesitates to demand extensive unpaid work.
biobak.quote: I'm not just gonna ask Biobak, "Hey, just do like 200 hours of unpaid labor,"

badub.summary: Badub will need to coordinate complex music requirements for the new Music/Mario Paint course.
badub.quote: It’s gonna be difficult to organize this with Badub, but I think it should work.

zeina.summary: Currently animating the Bowser fight; her work gates SFX/VFX integration.
zeina.quote: We're now waiting for the animations Zeina's making, then we're doing the VFX and SFX.

key_stories.title: Locking the Final Five Courses
key_stories.summary: Kaze entered the stream with only rough concepts for Over-world 3. Through live brainstorming with chat, he eliminated weaker ideas and committed to five distinct themes, each with an associated retro pipe.
key_stories.challenge: Needed five strong late-game levels but had only four viable ideas.
key_stories.process: Reviewed old list, debated pros/cons, merged or cut concepts, validated readability and novelty.
key_stories.outcome: Final roster: Frantic Fleet Factory, Wild West Valley, Music/Mario Paint world, Casino/Dr Mario, Mirror Comic City.
key_stories.key_quote: You need more ideas so you can discard the bad ones.

key_stories.title: Bowser Fight Nearing Completion
key_stories.summary: Logic and testing of the mid-game Bowser battle are done. The fight now requires Zeina’s animations plus sound and visual polish, after which Over-world 2 will be feature-complete.
key_stories.challenge: Implement a multi-phase fight with parachuting enemies, Yoshi ships, and Bowser pick-up exit.
key_stories.process: Coded mechanics, live-tested, noted remaining asset hooks.
key_stories.outcome: Waiting on Zeina; once assets arrive, Kaze will add intro cut-scene and polish.
key_stories.key_quote: The Bowser fight is basically finished. It just needs animations, sound effects and visual effects.

key_stories.title: Performance Breakthrough on Real Hardware
key_stories.summary: Kaze demonstrated that even previously ‘too complex’ levels now hold 30 FPS widescreen on an actual N64, outperforming expectations and making his 20 FPS interpolation demo impossible.
key_stories.challenge: Historical skepticism about hack complexity and N64 framerate limits.
key_stories.process: Ran demanding cave level on console; attempted to trigger lag.
key_stories.outcome: Could not dip below 30 FPS; performance milestone acknowledged.
key_stories.key_quote: I can't even get below 30 FPS… people were like, 'the N64 can't run this.'

key_stories.title: Switch from Twitch to YouTube
key_stories.summary: Kaze officially moved live development streams to YouTube, citing viewer experience concerns over Twitch ad load and better long-term viability.
key_stories.challenge: Twitch’s frequent ads harmed viewer engagement.
key_stories.process: Tested YouTube streams, informed community, adjusted notification workflow.
key_stories.outcome: Lower immediate viewership expected but considered a strategic improvement.
key_stories.key_quote: Twitch has so many ads, I can't stand it anymore.

open_questions.context: Kaze likes idea of a superhero comic level with mirrors switching to a haunted low-gravity raven world but no concrete mechanic details.
questions: How will the player trigger mirror transitions?
What visual cues differentiate the two worlds?
Will health drain or gravity changes be consistent throughout?

open_questions.context: Kaze proposed interactive note platforms that play sounds, unsure about layout or song choices.
questions: Will the level auto-compose a set melody or let players improvise?
What asset workload is expected from Biobak and Badub?
How will camera framing ensure readability of note platforms?

open_questions.context: Casino world will feature Dr Mario pill-drop level but gameplay and camera constraints are undefined.
questions: Will falling pills be timed hazards or player-controlled?
How will 3D camera convey vertical threats without unfair deaths?
What constitutes success/failure for the star?

open_questions.topic: Strike-Breaking Boss in Frantic Fleet Factory
open_questions.context: Kaze notes Bowser sends a boss to quell strike but did not decide identity or mechanics.
questions: Which enemy fits as the strike-breaking boss?
Will its defeat alter factory NPC behavior?
Does Zeina animate this boss as well?
